skill.name: ssh
skill.description: SSH remote access patterns and utilities. Connect to servers, manage keys, tunnels, and transfers.
skill.summary: SSH remote access patterns and utilities. Connect to servers, manage keys, tunnels, and transfers.
skill.author: Dicklesworthstone

security_audit.summary: Pure documentation skill containing only markdown content with SSH command examples. No executable code, no network calls, no file system access, and no external command execution capabilities. This is a knowledge-base skill for AI assistants.

content.value_statement: Need to manage remote servers securely. This skill provides ready-to-use SSH patterns for connections, file transfers, tunnels, and key management.
actual_capabilities: Connect to remote servers with various authentication methods
Execute commands on remote servers via SSH
Transfer files securely using SCP and rsync
Set up SSH tunnels and port forwarding
Manage SSH keys including generation and deployment
Configure jump hosts and bastion servers
limitations: Does not execute commands on actual servers
Does not store or manage SSH credentials
Does not modify SSH configuration files
Does not establish actual network connections

use_cases.title: Remote Server Management
use_cases.description: Connect to and manage Linux servers, execute commands, and set up secure tunnels.

use_cases.title: Code Deployment
use_cases.description: Deploy code using rsync, execute git commands remotely, and manage application servers.

use_cases.title: Infrastructure Operations
use_cases.description: Configure SSH access, manage keys across teams, and secure server connections.

prompt_templates.title: Basic Connection
prompt_templates.prompt: Show me how to connect to user@hostname with SSH, including how to specify a custom port and identity key.

prompt_templates.title: File Transfer
prompt_templates.prompt: How do I transfer a local directory to a remote server and sync changes efficiently?

prompt_templates.title: Tunnel Setup
prompt_templates.prompt: Set up an SSH tunnel to access a database on a remote server through localhost.

prompt_templates.title: Key Management
prompt_templates.prompt: Generate a secure SSH key and copy it to a server for passwordless authentication.

output_examples.input: How do I connect to myserver with SSH?
output: ssh myserver - Connects using settings from ~/.ssh/config
ssh -i ~/.ssh/myserver_key user@myserver - Uses specific identity file
ssh -J jumphost user@myserver - Connects through a jump host

best_practices: Use Ed25519 keys instead of RSA for better security and performance
Configure SSH multiplexing to reuse connections and speed up repeated access
Always verify host keys before connecting to prevent man-in-the-middle attacks
anti_patterns: Using password authentication instead of key-based access
Sharing private keys across team members or systems
Connecting to servers without verifying the host fingerprint

faq.question: Which key type should I use?
faq.answer: Ed25519 is recommended for most cases. It offers better security with smaller keys and faster performance than RSA.

faq.question: How do I avoid entering my passphrase repeatedly?
faq.answer: Use ssh-agent to load your key once. Add keys with ssh-add and they remain available for the session.

faq.question: Can I use this skill to connect through a bastion host?
faq.answer: Yes. Use the -J flag for command line or configure ProxyJump in ~/.ssh/config for persistent setup.

faq.question: Is my data safe when transferring files?
faq.answer: SSH encrypts all data in transit. Use rsync with compression for efficiency and verify checksums for critical transfers.

faq.question: Why is my SSH connection slow?
faq.answer: Enable connection multiplexing in ~/.ssh/config. Use ControlMaster with ControlPath for connection reuse.

faq.question: How does this compare to other remote access tools?
faq.answer: SSH provides secure command-line access. Unlike VNC or RDP, it is text-focused and works well for server management.
